fishergw.ringdown package¶

Submodules¶

fishergw.ringdown.fisher module¶

class fishergw.ringdown.fisher.Fisher(signal, integration_method=<function simps>, asd_name=None, detector=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

An object to load the power spectral density (PSD) and compute the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and the Fisher matrix elements of a gravitational wave signal. The SNR and the Fisher matrix are averaged over orientation angles. Recall that average over the inclination angle is already included in the initialization of RingdownMultimode .

Attributes:

signal (RingdownMultimode) – A RingdownMultimode waveform instance.

integration_method (scipy.integrate) – An integration method from the scipy.integrate subpackage.

psd (scipy.interpolate.interp1d) – Interpolant of the PSD. An instance of scipy.interpolate.interp1d.

fmin (float) – If asd_name is provided, fmin is the corresponding minimum frequency. Otherwise, fmin = None.

fmax (float) – If asd_name is provided, fmax is the corresponding maximum frequency. Otherwise, fmax = None.

Qavg (float) – Angle-averaging factor \(Q\). When load_psd() is called, the PSD is divided by \(Q^2\) to ensure that the SNR and the Fisher matrix elements are angle-averaged.

_detectors_ (dict) – Dictionary mapping built-in detectors to their asd_name and angle-averaging factor \(Q\). Built-in detectors are Advanced Ligo ('aligo'), Cosmic Explorer ('ce'), Einstein Telescope ('etd') and LISA ('lisa'). The following conventions hold for \(Q\):

'aLigo' and 'ce' are mapped to the factor \(Q=1/\sqrt{5}\) for a two-armed 90-degrees detector (see, e.g., Eq. (7.177) in [1]);

'etd' is mapped to \(Q=1/\sqrt{5}*\sqrt{3/2}\), the additional factor \(\sqrt{3/2}\) coming from the fact that ET is a three-armed 60-degrees detector with two channels (see Eq. (4) in https://arxiv.org/abs/1012.0908);

'lisa' is mapped to \(Q=1\), because the LISA sensitivity curve is already averaged over orientation and detector channels (see Eq.s (2,8-9) in https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.01944).

References:

[1] Maggiore, Michele. Gravitational waves: Volume 1: Theory and experiments. Vol. 1. Oxford university press, 2008.

__init__(signal, integration_method=<function simps>, asd_name=None, detector=None)[source]¶
Parameters

  • signal (RingdownMultimode) – A RingdownMultimode waveform instance.

  • integration_method (scipy.integrate object) – The integration method to compute the SNR and the Fisher matrix elements. Deafult: scipy.integrate.simps.

  • asd_name (filepath or None, optional) – The path to a text file with the tabulated ASD. If None, psd defaults to 1.0. If detector is not None, asd_name is read from the _detectors_ internal dictionary.

  • detector (str or None, optional) – If not None, must be one of ['aligo','ce','etd,'lisa'].

correlation_matrix(fm, svd=False)[source]¶

Returns the correlation matrix for a single (l,m) mode. If svd, the Fisher matrix is inverted with a singular value decomposition.

Parameters

fm – The Fisher matrix for a single (l,m) mode.

covariance_matrix(fm, svd=False)[source]¶

Returns the covariance matrix for a single (l,m) mode. If svd, the Fisher matrix is inverted with a singular value decomposition.

Parameters

fm – The Fisher matrix for a single (l,m) mode.

fisher_matrix(fmin=None, fmax=None, nbins=100000.0, logspace=False)[source]¶

Returns the Fisher matrix. Because it is block diagonal w.r.t. (l,m), the output is a dictionary of (l,m) couples and their corresponding blocks.

Parameters

  • fmin (float or None, optional) – Minimum frequency. If None, defaults to the minimum frequency set by the provided ASD file.

  • fmax (float or None, optional) – Maximum frequency. If None, defaults to the maximum frequency set by the provided ASD file.

  • nbins (float) – Binning of the integration domain. Default: 1e5.

  • logspace (Bool) – If True, integrations are performed in logspace over frequencies. Default: False.

static invert_matrix(matrix, svd=False, tol=1e-06)[source]¶

Returns the inverse of a matrix.

Parameters

  • matrix (numpy.array) – The input matrix.

  • svd (bool, optional) – If True a singular value decomposition is applied and principal directions with singular values smaller than tol are discarded. Default: False.

  • tol (float) – Directions with singular values smaller than tol are discarded when inverting the matrix. Default: 1e-6.

Return type

numpy.array

load_psd(asd_name, Qavg=1.0, logspace=False)[source]¶

Loads the PSD from a text file. Initializes the attributes psd, fmin, fmax and Qavg.

Parameters

  • asd_name (str) – name of the text file containing the ASD table. The file will be first looked into the fishergw/detector/ folder, then into the fishergw/detector/unofficial_asd/ folder. Otherwise, asd_name must be the full path of the text file.

  • Qavg (float) – Value of the angle-averaging factor. See the description in the Fisher attributes. Default: 1.

  • logspace (bool) – If True, the ASD is interpolated in logspace along the y-axis. Default: False.

sample(lm, covariance_matrix, nsamples=10000.0, keys=None)[source]¶

Returns sampled parameters for a given (l,m) from the corresponding covariance matrix.

Parameters

  • covariance_matrix – The covariance matrix for the (l,m) modes.

  • nsamples (float) – Number of samples to draw. Default: 1e4.

sigma1d(fm, svd=False)[source]¶

Returns the standard deviations of the 1D marginalized posteriors. If svd, the Fisher matrix is inverted with a singular value decomposition.

Parameters

fm – The Fisher matrix.

Returns

Dictionary mapping keys to the corresponding standard deviations.

Return type

dict

snr(fmin=None, fmax=None, nbins=100000.0, logspace=False)[source]¶

Returns the SNR of the signal.

Parameters

  • fmin (float or None, optional) – Minimum frequency. If None, defaults to the minimum frequency set by the provided PSD file.

  • fmax (float or None, optional) – Maximum frequency. If None, defaults to the maximum frequency set by the provided PSD file.

  • nbins (float) – Binning of the integration domain. Default: 1e5.

  • logspace (bool) – If True, integration is performed in logspace over frequencies. Default: False.

Return type

float

fishergw.ringdown.utils.final_mass(mass1, mass2, spin1, spin2, beta=0.0, gamma=0.0, method=1)[source]¶

Returns the final mass (in units of solar masses) of the Kerr black hole remnant of a quasi-circular binary black hole merger.

Parameters

  • mass1 (float) – Mass of the primary component [\(M_\odot\)].

  • mass2 (float) – Mass of the secondary component [\(M_\odot\)].

  • spin1 (float) – Dimensionless spin of the primary component.

  • spin2 (float) – Dimensionless spin of the secondary component.

  • beta (float) – Angle between spin1 and the z direction. Default: 0.

  • gamma (float) – Angle between spin2 and the z direction. Default: 0.

  • method – If 1, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/1206.3803. If 2, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07250. If 3, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/0807.2985. Default: 1.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.final_spin(mass1, mass2, spin1, spin2, beta=0.0, gamma=0.0, method=2)[source]¶

Returns the dimensionless final spin of the Kerr black hole remnant of a quasi-circular binary black hole merger.

Parameters

  • mass1 (float) – Mass of the primary component [\(M_\odot\)].

  • mass2 (float) – Mass of the secondary component [\(M_\odot\)].

  • spin1 (float) – Dimensionless spin of the primary component.

  • spin2 (float) – Dimensionless spin of the secondary component.

  • beta (float) – Angle between spin1 and the z direction. Default: 0.

  • gamma (float) – Angle between spin2 and the z direction. Default: 0.

  • method – If 1, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/0904.2577. If 2, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.01938. If 3, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.07250. If 4, uses the fit in https://arxiv.org/abs/0807.2985. Default: 2.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.invert_qnm_from_f(f, mode, method='fit2')[source]¶

Returns the masses (in units if solar masses) and dimensionless spins compatible with a given QNM frequency, assuming it is generated from the Kerr spectrum.

Parameters

  • f (float) – freqency [Hz].

  • mode (tuple) – the QNM numbers (l,m,n).

fishergw.ringdown.utils.invert_qnm_from_ff(f1, f2, mode1, mode2, method='fit2', qnm_invert={})[source]¶

Returns the mass (in units of solar masses) and the dimensionless spin corresponding to a pair of frequencies, assuming they are generated from the Kerr spectrum.

Parameters

  • f1 (float) – The first frequency [Hz].

  • f2 (float) – The second frequency [Hz].

  • mode1 (tuple) – The set (l,m,n) of angular and overtone numbers of the first frequency.

  • mode2 (tuple) – The set (l,m,n) of angular oand overtone numbers of the second frequency.

  • method – The method used to approximate the Kerr spectrum. See methods available in the qnm_Kerr function.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.invert_qnm_from_ftau(f1, tau2, mode1, mode2, method='fit2', qnm_invert={})[source]¶

Returns the mass (in units of solar masses) and the dimensionless spin corresponding to a frequency and a damping time, assuming they are generated from the Kerr spectrum.

Parameters

  • f1 (float) – The frequency [Hz].

  • f2 (float) – The damping time [s].

  • mode1 (tuple) – The set (l,m,n) of angular and overtone numbers of the frequency.

  • mode2 (tuple) – The set (l,m,n) of angular oand overtone numbers of the damping time.

  • method – The method used to approximate the Kerr spectrum. See methods available in the qnm_Kerr function.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.invert_qnm_from_tau(tau, mode, method='fit2')[source]¶

Returns the masses (in units of solar masses) and spins compatible with a given QNM damping time, assuming it is generated from the Kerr spectrum.

Parameters

  • tau (float) – damping time [s].

  • mode (tuple) – the QNM numbers (l,m,n).

fishergw.ringdown.utils.invert_qnm_from_tautau(tau1, tau2, mode1, mode2, method='fit2', qnm_invert={})[source]¶

Returns the mass (in units of solar masses) and the dimensionless spin corresponding to a pair of damping times, assuming they are generated from the Kerr spectrum.

Parameters

  • f1 (float) – The first damping time.

  • f2 (float) – The second damping time.

  • mode1 (tuple) – The set (l,m,n) of angular and overtone numbers of the first damping time.

  • mode2 (typle) – The set (l,m,n) of angular oand overtone numbers of the second damping time.

  • method – The method used to approximate the Kerr spectrum. See methods available in the qnm_Kerr function.

The use of fit1 methods can be badly posed for certain combination of modes, because the ratio tau1/tau2 is not monotonic. This is just an artifact of the fit1 method and it does not happen with other methods.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.qnm_Kerr(mass, spin, mode, method='interp', interp_qnm={})[source]¶

Returns the frequency and the damping time of a Kerr black hole for a given mass, spin and mode.

Parameters

  • mass (float) – Mass of the black hole [\(M_\odot\)].

  • spin (float) – Dimensionless spin.

  • mode (tuple) – Angular, azimuthal and overtone number in the form (l,m,n).

  • method – The method used to approximate the Kerr spectrum. If fit1, it uses the fits provided in https://arxiv.org/abs/gr-qc/0512160. If fit2, it uses the fits provided in the appendix of https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13961. If interp, it interpolates from the numerical tables provided in https://pages.jh.edu/eberti2/ringdown/. Deafault: interp.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.r_isco(spin)[source]¶

Returns the dimensionless ISCO radius for a given dimensionless spin.

Parameters

spin (float) – Dimensionless spin.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.ringdown_absolute_amplitudes(mass_f, mass_ratio, spin1, spin2, d_L, mode, method=1)[source]¶
fishergw.ringdown.utils.ringdown_relative_amplitudes(mass_ratio, spin1, spin2, mode, method=1)[source]¶

Returns the ratio of the ringdown amplitudes relative to the amplitude of the (2,2,0) mode.

Parameters

  • mass_ratio (float) – the mass ratio of the progenitor binary, defined as m1/m2>1.

  • spin1 (float) – the projection of the dimensionless spin of the first black hole component the z axis.

  • spin2 (float) – the projection of the dimensionless spin of the second component along the z axis.

  • mode (tuple) – Angular, azimuthal and overtnone number in the form (l,m,n).

  • method – if 1, use fits from https://arxiv.org/abs/1207.0399; if 2, use fits from https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.03260 in an updated form; if 3, uses EMOP fits from https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.02156. Default: 1.

fishergw.ringdown.utils.spherical_harmonics(angle, mode)[source]¶

fishergw.ringdown.waveform module¶

class fishergw.ringdown.waveform.RingdownLM(modes, freqs, taus, amps, phis, iota=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class to define the ringdown components with the same angular and azimuthal numbers (l,m) and including the fundamental tone (n=0) and possibly overtones (n>0).

Nabla()[source]¶

Returns the gradient of the plus and cross signal polarizations.

Return type

list of lambda functions, shape: len(self.keys)

__call__(f)[source]¶

Returns the plus and cross polarizations at a given frequency f, including multiplicative factors from the plus and cross spherical harmonics.

Parameters

f (float) – frequency

Return type

numpy.array, shape (2,)

__init__(modes, freqs, taus, amps, phis, iota=None)[source]¶
Parameters

  • modes (tuple) – a list specifying the corresponding modes, each as a tuple of angular, azimuthal and overtone numbers (l,m,n).

  • freqs (list) – frequencies of the tones in ascending order starting from n=0.

  • taus (list) – damping times of the tones in ascending order starting from n=0.

  • amps – amplitudes of the tones in ascending order starting from n=0.

  • phis – phases of the tones in ascending order starting from n=0.

  • iota (float or None) – the inclination angle, which determines the values of the plus and cross spherical harmonics. If None, spherical harmonics are averaged over the inclination angle. Default: None.

diff_(argument)[source]¶

Returns the derivative of the plus and cross signal polarizations w.r.t. argument.

Parameters

argument (str) – argument of the derivative.

Return type

tuple of lambda functions, shape (2,)

hc()[source]¶

Returns the fourier transform of the cross polarization of the signal.

hp()[source]¶

Returns the fourier transform of the plus polarization of the signal.

class fishergw.ringdown.waveform.RingdownMultimode(modes, freqs, taus, amps, phis, iota=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class to define a multimode ringdown signal as a superimposition of damped sinusoids.

__call__(f)[source]¶

Call self as a function.

__init__(modes, freqs, taus, amps, phis, iota=None)[source]¶
Parameters

  • freqs (list) – frequencies of each mode.

  • taus (list) – damping times of each mode.

  • amps – amplitudes of each mode.

  • phis – phases of each mode.

  • iota (float or None) – inclination angle. If None, polarizations are averaged over the inclination angle. Default: None.

  • modes (list) – a list specifying the corresponding modes, each as a set of angular, azimuthal and overtone numbers (l,m,n).
